stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the 3D layout for a new milk bar/saloon area within the cowboy-themed level. Key activities included designing the interior space, brainstorming a secret room, implementing a new 'strong Dry Bones' enemy mechanic, and creating a window lighting effect. The stream also featured extensive discussions on Kaze's creative philosophies regarding level design, music theory, and color theory, as well as a decision to rework an older level.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is designing a milk bar saloon level which includes a secret room where enemies drink 'chalky milk,' an illegal substance in this world. The player will overhear conversations to find the hidden entrance.
development_findings.quote: There's going to be a secret room where a bunch of bad guys sit around the table drinking chalky milk. And you're going to be in here. You're going to be going to tables and you're going to be overhearing their conversations.

development_findings.summary: A gameplay mechanic is being added where Dry Bones in the cowboy level are immune to standard jumps and require a ground pound to defeat, with the lore explanation being that their bones are strong from drinking milk.
development_findings.quote: The Dry Bones in them hills, they got real strong bones. They spent their whole life drinking milk, so your little jumps ain't gonna do much.

development_findings.summary: Kaze feels some planned level themes are uninspired and wants to pivot to a more creative, dream-like ideation process similar to what he used for his previous hack, *Lost Impact*.
development_findings.quote: I was looking at RTYI and I think we have a similar idea density. So that's good. But I am noticing, I find that the Ulrich theme is a little uninspired... And usually all the themes in Lost Impact were just things that literally came to me in a dream.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has decided to completely redesign a 'lame' water raft section in the existing Course 2, replacing it with a more engaging platforming sequence.
development_findings.quote: We're gonna rework part of course 2. The Divine Dino Domain. There's an inside section where it's just like a water raft going around and you collect red coins. It's lame as fuck. Instead, it's gonna be mostly a platforming section.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is considering a physical release of the game's soundtrack on an N64 cartridge, contingent on a new runtime audio decompression technology being developed by the LibDragon team.
development_findings.quote: I'm thinking maybe it would be cool if we made a cartridge with all the RTYI songs and sold that separately.

development_findings.summary: Kaze discusses his preference for C over C++, arguing that the core principles of object-oriented programming can be applied in C and that he finds C++'s features unnecessary and annoying for this project.
development_findings.quote: Being object-oriented is not a property of the language. It's a property of your code. I can do object-oriented programming in C. Who's going to stop me?

development_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a deep-seated frustration with standard 12-tone music theory, wishing instead to compose music using a continuous spectrum of raw frequencies to achieve 'perfect' harmonic ratios.
development_findings.quote: I don't like music theory cuz why the fuck is it 12 notes. I get that the ratios when you have a 12 tone scale kinda line up nicely with actual ratios, but why the fuck can't we use the actual ratios? That would be so much better.

development_findings.summary: Kaze rejects popular color theory as arbitrary 'fiction,' stating he prefers 'color science' and does not adhere to the conventional color wheel for the game's art direction.
development_findings.quote: Fuck the color wheel. It's so arbitrary who decided that the color wheel was like the colors that go well together... It's not deduced, it's invented. It's fiction.

development_findings.summary: The cowboy level currently has a polygon count of around 14,000, split over three areas, with the main area being 10,000, which Kaze deems acceptable.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that creation is the fundamental purpose of human existence and he cannot imagine a life without it.
context_findings.quote: What would be the point of an existence where you don't create? That's like the whole purpose of the human soul. And you're gonna go without it? Damn. Are you even alive anymore at that point?

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a philosophical stance on modding ethics, believing that those who modify commercial games should not object when their own work is modified by others.
context_findings.quote: I feel like if you hack someone else's game without their consent you should also be fine with someone hacking your hack against your consent. That seems logical to me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is committed to working within the original N64's 8MB cartridge limitation, viewing it as a core part of the creative challenge.
context_findings.quote: I'm not interested in ever using more than 8MB just because the original N64 games didn't do it. And going beyond the original limitations is just kinda against the spirit of the challenge.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is a proponent of using AI tools like ChatGPT as a 'better Google' to accelerate development tasks like generating dialogue or code snippets, while stressing that one must still possess the underlying skills.
context_findings.quote: I feel like people that are saying it's useless are just coping maybe because they're useless.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a hot take that most people don't have an innate favorite color but rather invent one when asked as a child and adopt it as a personality trait.
context_findings.quote: I feel like what happens is that someone asked them what their favorite color is and they just make something up and now that's the personality they're stuck with.

context_findings.summary: Kaze casually mentions that the game's story, which apparently involves a 'slavery plot,' is too dark and needs to be overhauled.
context_findings.quote: The whole slavery plot is a little bit dark for a Mario game. Actually, we can just reuse this texture now. Yeah, I think I like this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze explains his habit of referring to people as 'males' and 'females' is a deliberate choice to de-emphasize human exceptionalism and frame people as part of the animal kingdom.
context_findings.quote: The reason I like doing that is because it kind of underscores that humans are still animals when you call them females and males. It's um, I just like it. Puts humans from the pedestal down to the world.

context_findings.summary: Kaze discusses plans to sell merchandise, including stickers, through Pixel Empire and briefly questions the legal assurances he receives from them regarding IP usage.
Kaze mentions his full-time job is as a C++ programmer for Unreal Engine.

biobak.summary: Kaze credits Biobak with developing a specific visual technique for creating window light effects using additive blending and decals, which Kaze implements during the stream.
biobak.quote: Dude, Biobak, we need to use your window technique here. Look at this. It's so perfect, dude.

biobak.summary: Kaze considered using a 'combiner' from Biobak for the saloon floor but decided against it because it was incompatible with his goal of having a multi-textured surface.
biobak.quote: Unfortunately I can't use biomex combiner. It's not gonna work in this situation. Because I do want the multi textured floor.

badub.summary: Badub's music, particularly the desert theme, is highly praised by Kaze and the chat.
badub.quote: Everything Banduke makes a banger, true.

badub.summary: Kaze intends to financially compensate Badub for the soundtrack if they proceed with the plan to sell a physical OST cartridge.
badub.quote: I'm definitely gonna pay Barduke for the OST if we do end up making that cartridge.

zeina.summary: Kaze asks Zeina in chat if she is handling the animations for the Dry Bones enemies, indicating her role extends to enemy animation.
zeina.quote: Are you also doing the drybones animations?

zeina.summary: Zeina suggested the 'I hate video games' concept for a sticker as part of Kaze's merchandise line.
zeina.quote: Zayna thought the I hate video game thing is good.

zeina.summary: Zeina was the second most active chatter in Kaze's Twitch stream recap, after Lilaa.

key_stories.title: Pivoting Level Themes for Inspiration
key_stories.summary: Feeling that the planned later levels for the game were creatively lacking, Kaze decided to pivot his design strategy. He reflected on how his best ideas for a past project came from dreams and resolved to seek out more unique, personally inspiring concepts, leading him to scrap old plans in favor of a new 'space station' level idea.
key_stories.challenge: The planned themes for the game's later levels felt uninspired and derivative compared to Kaze's previous work.
key_stories.process: Kaze reflected on his creative process for a previous project, *Lost Impact*, realizing its most memorable ideas came from his dreams. He then brainstormed new, more 'crazy' themes live on stream, evaluating ideas like a comic book level, a dream level, and a space station, ultimately committing to the space station concept.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to abandon the uninspiring pre-planned ideas and adopt a new creative approach based on finding concepts that feel personally exciting and cool, like things from a dream. He settled on a 'space station' level and decided to rework an existing 'lame' section of Course 2.
key_stories.key_quote: I find that some of the other themes I had planned for course 13, 14, 14 and the side level. Maybe they're also a little bit uninspired compared to how they were in Lost Impact. So we probably want different themes.

key_stories.title: The Milk-Strengthened Dry Bones
key_stories.summary: To make the Dry Bones in the saloon level special, Kaze implemented a new mechanic based on the lore that they drank a lot of milk. This made them immune to normal jumps, requiring a ground pound instead. He then used AI to write flavorful dialogue for an NPC to teach this mechanic to the player.
key_stories.challenge: How to make the Dry Bones enemies in the cowboy-themed level feel unique and integrated with the world's lore.
key_stories.process: The idea originated from a chat suggestion about milk making bones strong. Kaze embraced this, deciding it would translate into a new defeat condition for the Dry Bones. He then used ChatGPT to generate several versions of cowboy-style dialogue to serve as a lore drop and tutorial for the player.
key_stories.outcome: A new enemy variant was created that requires a ground pound to defeat instead of a simple jump. This mechanic is explained to the player through in-game NPC dialogue, tying the gameplay directly to the level's unique 'milk bar' theme.
key_stories.key_quote: Howdy partner just a bit of cowboy wisdom for you them dry bones up on them hills they're tough as all leather spent their days guzzling milk so wrecking your little hops ain't gonna make a dent.

key_stories.title: The Philosophy of Frequencies vs. Notes
key_stories.summary: During a debate about music, Kaze revealed his rejection of standard 12-tone music theory. He argued for composing with raw frequencies to achieve perfect mathematical harmonies, rather than using the 'limiting' system of discrete notes. This story showcases his deeply analytical and unconventional approach to creative systems.
key_stories.challenge: A discussion on music led Kaze to articulate his highly unconventional philosophy on music composition, contrasting it with standard music theory.
key_stories.process: When music theory was brought up, Kaze explained his dislike for the 12-tone system, arguing it was a limiting approximation of true harmonic ratios. He stated his desire to compose with a continuous spectrum of raw frequencies. He defended his position using mathematical concepts like countable vs. uncountable infinities to illustrate why he finds the current system restrictive.
key_stories.outcome: The discussion provided a deep insight into Kaze's analytical, first-principles approach to creative work. It shows he is willing to question and discard fundamental conventions (like the 12-tone scale) in pursuit of a theoretical 'purer' or more mathematically perfect form of expression.
key_stories.key_quote: I want non-quantized notes. It will literally be impossible to have names for that.
